results.firPara: Today is the birthday of that wonderful football innovator the late Jimmy Hill so its a shame that the first rumour the Mill has to report to you is that hackneyed old saw about Chelsea wanting Edinson Cavani. It has been hard to know during the last three years whether the Paris Saint-Germain striker really has been yearning for a move to the Premier League or has just been cultivating a vibe of existential torment to fit in with the hip set on the Rive Gauche, but tales of his desire to leave France for England have become suitably cliched.
results.secPara: Mind you, the Mill rather thought thered be some quiet on that front since Zlatan Ibrahimovic got out of the strikers way at PSG but word is that Chelsea are determined to keep picking at the sore because Diego Costa is off to pick fights elsewhere despite his mooted move back to Atlético Madrid seemingly having broken down a couple of days ago. And if Cavani admits that he is happy in Paris, after all, then Chelsea will just keep trying to retread old ground and offer Everton around £50m to let Romelu Lukaku do likewise.
results.webTitle: Football transfer rumours: Edinson Cavani to leave PSG for Chelsea?

results.firPara: The Manchester United manager expects Zlatan to take the Premier League by storm, plans to keep Juan Mata and will continue with Wayne Rooney as captain
results.secPara: José Mourinho was in relaxed mood as he gave his first in-depth interview as the Manchester United manager at the team hotel in Shanghai. The club is on its pre-season tour of China but he is already targeting Uniteds 21st top-division title and is clear he wants to continue as manager beyond his three-year contract.
results.webTitle: José Mourinho: ‘Ibrahimovic’s motivation is high and his body is amazing’

results.firPara: The astute former Sunderland manager will bring clearness of thought and commonsense to his new job, plus a down-to-earth openness that will encourage his England players to pursue a fresh path
results.secPara: Sam Allardyce chortled. The man chosen to manage England – not that he knew it at the time – had just been asked what he thought about the Football Associations latest brainwave, namely employing specialist in possession and out of possession coaches.
results.webTitle: Sam Allardyce has the power to help England see the wood for the trees | Louise Taylor

results.firPara: David Moyes is to replace Sam Allardyce at Sunderland, with his appointment expected swiftly once the outgoing managers role in charge of England is confirmed.
results.secPara: Talks between Moyes and Ellis Short, Sunderlands owner, and Martin Bain, the clubs chief executive, are understood to have reached an advanced stage. The former Preston, Everton, Manchester United and Real Sociedad manager, long admired by Short, was approached soon after Allardyce was interviewed by the Football Association last week.
results.webTitle: David Moyes to replace Sam Allardyce as Sunderland manager

results.firPara: In todays Fiver Englands next manager
results.secPara: In todays Fiver Englands next manager
results.webTitle: The Fiver | An exhaustive search of Sunderland and Hull

results.firPara: The NYC FC-Red Bulls rivalry may seem forced, but remember its only in its second season, and MLS remains a young league. These things take time to grow
results.secPara: The NYC FC-Red Bulls rivalry may seem forced, but remember its only in its second season, and MLS remains a young league. These things take time to grow
results.webTitle: Don't mock the Hudson River derby. True rivalries don't happen overnight

results.firPara: With that news, its time to close the live blog down for the time being, although if theres any developments, we will be back. Otherwise, lets do it all again tomorrow.
results.secPara: We have some news! And the news is... Sam Allardyce probably wont be confirmed as England manager today, as the FA and Sunderland are still ironing out compensation. Heres more from Louise Taylor
results.webTitle: Sam Allardyce named new England manager – as it almost happened

results.firPara: Sam Allardyces appointment as the Englands manager is expected to be delayed until Friday to allow Sunderland and the Football Association time to finish haggling over compensation. Roy Hodgsons successor is then likely to be presented to the media at some point next week.
results.secPara: With David Moyes set to be swiftly installed as Allardyces successor on Wearside, negotiations are not regarded as a major problem but reflect the anger and frustration of the Sunderland owner, Ellis Short, at the manner in which the FA poached his manager.
results.webTitle: Sam Allardyce’s England appointment delayed by haggling over compensation

results.firPara: Spain have appointed the former Porto manager Julen Lopetegui as their new coach to replace Vicente del Bosque.
results.secPara: The former goalkeeper, who was recently linked with a move to England to replace Kenny Jackett at Wolverhampton Wanderers, has coached Spain at youth level extensively, having led the national under-19, under-20 and under-21 sides.
results.webTitle: Spain appoint Julen Lopetegui as coach to replace Vicente del Bosque

results.firPara: • Manchester United manager says he has three targets for last major signing
results.secPara: José Mourinho has said he has three different choices for his final major transfer, of which Paul Pogba is only one. Although the Manchester United manager did not directly name the Juventus midfielder, he was clear that Ed Woodward, the executive vice-chairman, has been told of a trio of players for the position.
results.webTitle: José Mourinho coy on Paul Pogba and hints at other options
